author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Jim Windolf
title: Joe Kahn Is Named Next Executive Editor of The New York Times
description: Mr. Kahn, 57, will take over a newsroom undergoing enormous change.
content: Joseph F. Kahn, a Pulitzer Prize-winning China correspondent who rose to lead the international desk of The New York Times, and then as managing editor helped steer the newspaper into the digital era, has been selected to be The Times’s next executive editor, the top newsroom job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Lemann
title: Thomas Piketty’s Radical Plan to Redistribute Wealth
description: Piketty’s “A Brief History of Equality” looks at centuries of economic improvement and suggests new reforms for modern societies.
content: A BRIEF HISTORY OF EQUALITYBy Thomas Piketty
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Mohn
title: Can A.I. All but End Car Crashes? The Potential Is There.
description: Well before self-driving cars become a reality, there are simpler approaches that can make roads much safer.
content: This article is the last in a limited series on artificial intelligence’s potential to solve everyday problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Some European airlines lift mask requirements on trans-Atlantic flights.
description: British Airways and Virgin Atlantic say face coverings on flights to the United States are a personal choice.
content: After a federal judge struck down the United States mask mandate for planes, trains, buses and other public transportation on Monday, several European airlines made mask-wearing optional for passengers on their trans-Atlantic flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: The Right Likes Book Bans. That Fuels the Left’s Cancel Culture.
description: Recreational puritanism begets itself.
content: Growing up in the 1970s, one got a good snootful of what today might be wrongly described as critical race theory: The film “Sounder,” in the wake of a prominent novel, offered a searing depiction of sharecropping. The made-for-TV epic “The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman,” also based on a novel, took us through a sweep of history from slavery to segregation. The “Roots” mini-series, watched by millions (all at the same time, in a way that’s probably hard to imagine for those too young to remember life before D.V.R.s), portrayed the trans-Atlantic slave trade and plantation barbarity in a way American audiences hadn’t seen. As Charlayne Hunter-Gault reported for The Times in 1977, a Black economist in Philadelphia said, “It has made the brutality of slavery more vivid for me than anything I’ve seen or read.” To refresh a sense of what an event “Roots” was at the time, recall that the cast included some of the biggest names of the day, including John Amos, Lloyd Bridges and Sandy Duncan. Cicely Tyson, who passed away last year, starred in “Sounder,” “Miss Jane Pittman” and “Roots.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: M.R.I.s Are Finding Connections Between Our Brain Activity and Psychology
description: How might we leverage knowing that a particular neurological feature makes someone more vulnerable to autism or Alzheimer’s or more likely to achieve academically?
content: In March, neuroscientists and psychiatrists from the School of Medicine at Washington University, St. Louis, along with colleagues elsewhere, published a study in the journal Nature that sparked widespread discussion in their fields. Researchers, the study noted, are increasingly using magnetic resonance imaging — which can reveal the brain’s structure and activity — to try to find links between what is seen on an M.R.I., like cortical thickness or patterns of connection, and complicated psychological traits, like cognitive ability or mental-health conditions. In theory, such so-called brain-wide association studies could yield incredibly valuable insights. Knowing that a particular neurological feature makes someone more vulnerable to autism, Alzheimer’s or another disorder, for example, could help predict, prevent or treat that condition. Likewise, if we can link certain features to desirable traits, like academic achievement, it might be possible to take advantage of that knowledge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saskia Solomon
title: Drawn and Caricatured: French Cartoonists on the Campaign Trail
description: Cartoonists play a high-profile role in France’s political discourse, and they have been busy drawing the presidential candidates as the race approaches its end.
content: PARIS — There is little time left until the French choose their next president on Sunday, and image is important. As media teams flutter around the two remaining candidates, President Emmanuel Macron and the far-right leader Marine Le Pen, the nation’s political cartoonists are out in force, ready to accentuate even the smallest slip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Star Ferry, ‘Emblem of Hong Kong,’ May Sail Into History After 142 Years
description: Launched in 1880, the ferry has witnessed both Hong Kong’s transformation into a global financial hub and its history of protests. But battered by a pandemic, the service is struggling to survive.
content: HONG KONG — On a damp Monday morning in Hong Kong, Freeman Ng looked out from the upper deck of the Star Ferry as it approached land. A sailor tossed a heavy rope to a colleague on the pier, who looped it around a bollard as the swoosh of the waves crashed against the green and white vessel pulling in from Victoria Harbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: A judge ruled that Amazon must reinstate a Staten Island worker who was fired.
description: The judge said the worker was “unlawfully” fired two years ago after a pandemic safety protest at a company warehouse.
content: A judge ruled on Monday that Amazon must reinstate and pay lost wages to a worker the company “unlawfully” fired two years ago after a protest at its fulfillment center on Staten Island, the same warehouse that recently voted in a landmark election to unionize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Letizia Battaglia, Photographer of Mafia Brutality, Dies at 87
description: Her images of victims on the streets of Palermo were stamped on the nation’s consciousness as she challenged the grip mobsters had on her native Sicily.
content: ROME — Letizia Battaglia, a photographer who chronicled years of Sicilian Mafia bloodshed in Palermo, Italy, in unflinching images that became ingrained in the national consciousness, died on Wednesday at her home in Palermo. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Meltzer
title: Each White Flag: A Life Lost to Covid
description: Mourners from across the country gathered on the National Mall to honor loved ones.
content: In September 2021, more than 660,000 white flags were planted on the National Mall in Washington, D.C., as part of a participatory art project by Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg titled “In America: Remember.” It was not the first time the National Mall served as a memorial for those lost to a pandemic; in 1987 the Names Project AIDS Memorial Quilt had its first public display there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: To Tip, or Not to Tip?
description: Automated payment and the spread of tipping to every corner of the food-service business have helped workers weather the pandemic. But some consumers feel overwhelmed.
content: Last year, Anna Johnson found herself using an electronic screen to pay for a pickup order at a bakery in Phoenix, a normal enough experience at many food businesses she frequents. But this time, she was bewildered when the machine recommended that she tip as much as 35 percent — on cookies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Heather Murphy
title: For Airlines, the Mask Mandate Couldn’t End Soon Enough
description: It created tensions between flight attendants and noncompliant passengers, but some travelers are worried about what comes next.
content: For two years, covered faces in airports and on airplanes were a persistent reminder of the hold that the coronavirus had on air travel. The end of the mask mandate on planes and other forms of transportation this week marked the latest advance in the airline industry’s effort to return to normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Inflation, Interest and the Housing Paradox
description: Hike we must, but build we should.
content: One of the occupational hazards of my profession is having people ask me what’s going to happen to the market. I’m never sure whether to give the answer attributed to various famous financial titans — it will fluctuate — or to reply, more accurately, “God knows.” But some predictions seem safe. Clearly, the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates repeatedly over the months ahead, continuing that process until there are clear signs that inflation is coming down to tolerable levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: The W.H.O. chief arrives in India, amid a tussle over Covid death estimates.
description: The director general of the World Health Organization arrived in India on Monday for a visit that comes amid a dispute over India’s Covid-19 death count.
content: The director general of the World Health Organization arrived in India on Monday for a visit that comes amid a dispute over India’s Covid-19 death count.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: A Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine.
content: Russian forces launched a ground assault along a nearly 300-mile front in eastern Ukraine, according to Ukrainian officials, after hitting the country with one of the most intense missile barrages in weeks. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Here’s how to handle some of the most irritating workplace habits when you return to the office.
description: After two years of working from home during the pandemic, and plenty of false starts, employees are officially heading back to work as the R.T.O., or return to office, is in full swing.
content: After two years of working from home during the pandemic, and plenty of false starts, employees are officially heading back to work as the R.T.O., or return to office, is in full swing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: China and Russia Are Giving Authoritarianism a Bad Name
description: Moscow overreached on Ukraine and Beijing on Covid, and now they’re paying for their hubris.
content: The last decade looked like a good one for authoritarian regimes and a challenging one for democratic ones. Cybertools, drones, facial recognition technology and social networks seemed to make efficient authoritarians even more efficient and democracies increasingly ungovernable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Eric Krupke, Diana Nguyen, Lynsea Garrison, M.J. Davis Lin, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Cost of Dissidence in Russia
description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s us-versus-them framing of the war has set the country up for a new and dark phase domestically.
content: Nearly two months into the war in Ukraine, many Russians have gone from shock and denial to support for their troops and anger at the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: A Nonbinary Swan, on Pointe
description: Ashton Edwards, an apprentice at Pacific Northwest Ballet, is part of a rising generation of gender nonconforming dancers questioning ballet’s rigid gender roles.
content: Ashton Edwards’s ballet dreams were dashed at age 6. Raised as a boy in the Midwest, Edwards, who is nonbinary and now uses they/them pronouns, had hoped ballet would allow them to explore their truest self. “I wanted to be one of those beautiful, ethereal people on pointe,” they said, referring to the reinforced shoes that allow dancers to stand on the tips of their toes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Jan Ransom
title: Chaos at Rikers Could Lead to Federal Court Control, U.S. Attorney Says
description: Damian Williams wrote that his office might have no choice but to seek “aggressive relief” for the serious problems at the jail.
content: The U.S. attorney in Manhattan raised the prospect on Tuesday of placing Rikers Island under a federal court’s control, an extraordinary step that would amount to a no-confidence vote in New York City’s ability to reverse the crisis that has intensified at the jail complex over the past 18 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Ukrainian Children and Caregivers Are Being Separated at U.S. Border
description: Under a policy designed to protect young refugees from trafficking, Ukrainian children are being temporarily removed from caretakers who are not their parents.
content: LOS ANGELES — After Iryna Merezhko persuaded her sister in Ukraine that her young nephew should join her in Los Angeles to wait out the war, she traveled halfway around the globe to pick him up. “I told him it would be a California vacation,” she recalled. “We would go to Disneyland, Universal Studios, the beach.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Millions move closer to student loan forgiveness with one-time government waivers.
description: A set of piecemeal fixes is intended to address longstanding administrative failures by the government’s loan servicers.
content: In its latest attempt to fix widespread breakdowns in the federal student loan payment system, the Education Department said on Tuesday that it would use one-time waivers and adjustments to retroactively credit millions of borrowers with additional payments toward loan forgiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Cusk
title: When I Went Away From the World
description: The novelist Rachel Cusk’s pursuit of finality had taken her further and further away. She never considered how she was going to get back.
content: We stood by the ruffled water on the breezy Greek shore, in an uncertain light of evening. It was early spring, Sunday, a feast day, and we were told there were celebrations earlier, of which this was the aftermath — this silence in the village and beside the water, beside the shuttered houses and the empty little pier, where the sea grasses bent this way and that in the wind and the sky was as though absorbed in a private process of transformation, a movement out of winter that had not yet been accomplished. This was not our country: We had only just arrived, and the celebrations had not included us. We didn’t mind, having paid the price of inclusion earlier in our lives. In fact our feelings had become more or less irrelevant, without our entirely noticing. So that the old terror, of exclusion — or abandonment perhaps — didn’t trouble us, any more than the thistledown troubled us whirling softly off the vegetation by the water. We stood and waited for the boat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Abrams
title: Climate-Change Risks Get the Attention of Real Estate Investors
description: They are thinking more seriously about flooding, but a lack of established standards for assessing development projects is challenging their efforts.
content: In Charleston, S.C., climate change is becoming impossible to ignore. In the historic city center, “sunny day” flooding occurs roughly once a week, making downtown difficult to traverse. Groundwater has begun to burble up in spots. And after a downpour, much of the region is susceptible to flooding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Democratic Dollars Flow Once Again to Likely Lost Causes
description: New fund-raising figures show emerging Democratic stars like Marcus Flowers in Georgia and Gary Chambers Jr. in Louisiana, with no clear path to victory.
content: Gary Chambers Jr. burst onto the national scene in 2020 with a viral video of him castigating the racism of the East Baton Rouge school district. Now, he has captured the hearts and wallets of young liberals with a video for his improbable Senate campaign that shows him smoking a large joint and calling for the legalization of marijuana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Bombards the East
description: Moscow’s military offensive in eastern Ukraine has begun.
content: Moscow declared that its offensive for control over Ukraine’s east was underway as it bombarded hundreds of targets overnight across the country’s industrial heartland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 6, Episode 2: Do the Hustle
description: Gus and the cartel chase Nacho, Kim and Jimmy pursue Howard — and everyone is conning someone.
content: This recap is for Episode 2 of the back-to-back season opener; click here for the recap of Episode 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on a Deathbed Request
description: Should it be honored if the person survives?
content: Lisa writes: When my husband seemed to be on his deathbed, he asked if we could move to Mars when it became possible. I said yes. He survived. My husband believes our oral contract stands and must be fulfilled when the opportunity arrives. I believe it is null and void. ————
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Rauch
title: The Strange History of American Conservatism
description: Matthew Continetti’s “The Right” traces the twists and turns of the right wing’s policies and philosophy.
content: THE RIGHTThe Hundred-Year War for American ConservatismBy Matthew Continetti
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Alfie Allen Gets in the Zone with Gospel Music and Pineapples
description: Known for portraying the luckless Theon Greyjoy on “Game of Thrones,” the British actor shares the items that are helping him prep for his Broadway debut.
content: In the Martin McDonagh play “Hangmen,” set in the 1960s, a mysterious fellow named Mooney turns up out of the blue in a London pub. He describes himself as “vaguely menacing,” but he is also rather coolly charismatic: This is a “spiffy young devil,” as The New York Times’s Ben Brantley put it in his review of the play’s Off Broadway premiere in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Should Parents Give Children More Responsibility at Younger Ages?
description: When did you first go on an errand or to school alone? Do you think parents today are overprotective?
content: At what age do you think children should be allowed to play outdoors without supervision? Take a walk or bike ride alone? Go to a local store? Take public transportation? Stay home alone?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Should you still wear a mask?
description: As coronavirus infections tick up across the United States, there’s a lot of confusion about if, and when, to wear a mask.
content: As coronavirus infections tick up across the United States, there’s a lot of confusion about if, and when, to wear a mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Your Office Is More Annoying Than You Remembered. Here’s How to Handle It.
description: The gossip, the loud talker and the nosy colleague are all manageable with the right mind-set.
content: After two years of working from home during the pandemic, and plenty of false starts, employees are officially heading back to work as the R.T.O., or return to office, is in full swing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Effort to Remove Marjorie Taylor Greene From Ballot Can Proceed, Judge Says
description: The case that Ms. Greene unsuccessfully sought to have dismissed mirrors efforts against other Republicans centered on the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
content: A federal judge cleared the way on Monday for a group of Georgia voters to move forward with legal efforts seeking to disqualify Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene from running for re-election to Congress, citing her role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Moderna says trial results suggest redesigned vaccines can better protect against variants.
description: Researchers combined Moderna’s existing vaccine with one designed to attack the Beta variant, and found it provided a stronger defense against several variants.
content: Moderna announced preliminary results Tuesday from its study of a coronavirus vaccine intended to protect against variants, saying the findings show it can design a vaccine that offers better, longer-lasting protection than its initial product.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David de Jong
title: They Are the Heirs of Nazi Fortunes, and They Aren’t Apologizing
description: In a country that is celebrated for its culture of reckoning and remembrance, the richest families are often an exception.
content: The backbone of Germany’s economy today is the car industry. It’s not just that it accounts for about 10 percent of G.D.P.; brands like Porsche, Mercedes, BMW and Volkswagen are recognized around the world as symbols of German industrial ingenuity and excellence. These companies spend millions on branding and advertising to ensure they are thought of this way. They spend less money and energy on discussing their roots. These corporations can trace their success directly back to Nazis: Ferdinand Porsche persuaded Hitler to put Volkswagen into production. His son, Ferry Porsche, who built up the company, was a voluntary SS officer. Herbert Quandt, who built BMW into what it is today, committed war crimes. So did Friedrich Flick, who came to control Daimler-Benz. Unlike Mr. Quandt, Mr. Flick was convicted at Nuremberg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Charlie Savage
title: Biden Administration May Appeal Ruling That Voided Travel Mask Mandate
description: If the C.D.C. decides there is a public health basis for trying to reinstate and extend the mask mandate, the Justice Department will swiftly file an appeal.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced on Tuesday that it intends to appeal a Florida judge’s ruling that struck down a federal mask requirement on airplanes, trains, buses and other public transportation — but only if the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention decides that extending the measure is necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Jorge Drexler’s Music Connects Genres, Generations and Continents
description: After three decades of making albums, the Academy Award-winning songwriter is still blending science and poetry, still reaching out to younger artists and still learning.
content: A recent video chat with the songwriter Jorge Drexler quickly turned into a whirlwind music lesson as he demonstrated how a beat could travel among continents and cultures. From his home studio in Madrid, with guitars on the floor and books and family photos on his shelves, Drexler dug into the cross-rhythms of a soleá por bulerías, the flamenco rhythm that underlies the title song of his new album, “Tinta y Tiempo” (“Ink and Time”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: How Much Should You Be Asked to Donate for a Colleague’s Gift?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when co-workers may feel pressured into making a donation at the office — and more.
content: I am a doctor. My colleague’s spouse was recently diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer. I privately communicated my support and offered to help, even though they’re very self-sufficient and have lots of resources, both financially and emotionally.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: At Holy Time, A War Splits the Faithful
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 19, 2022.
content: “How can you accept prayers for the patriarch who is blessing the soldiers trying to kill your son?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: A Cauliflower-Free Approach to Vegan Dining
description: These restaurants will convince even the most reluctant diner that vegan dining is worth seeking out.
content: Years ago, my friend Sera, already a vegetarian, decided to adopt a vegan diet. And I’ll admit: I was unsure how we might do one of our favorite things — going out to eat at new restaurants — with these dietary “restraints” in place. Good news: It was totally fine, great even, just as long as the only vegan option wasn’t cauliflower steak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: ‘Better Call Saul’ Recap, Season 6 Premiere: Run Nacho, Run
description: In a dazzling opener to Season 6 of “Better Call Saul,” Jimmy and Kim scheme, Lalo plots and Gus tries to rescue Nacho, who is lamming it in Mexico.
content: This recap is for Episode 1 of the back-to-back season opener only; click here for Episode 2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: They Thought Remodeling Could Wait. Then a Tree Fell on the House.
description: As one Westchester family discovered, there’s no better time to renovate than when you’ve already got a hole in the roof.
content: When Dana and Jay Vasser bought a midcentury-modern house in Pelham Manor, N.Y., in Westchester County, they figured they might renovate it — at some point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Belkin
title: The Work-Life-Balance Library Welcomes Another Title
description: Lara Bazelon’s “Ambitious Like A Mother” is the latest addition to a tall pile of books for women who are pondering issues of employment and children.
content: AMBITIOUS LIKE A MOTHERWhy Prioritizing Your Career Is Good for Your KidsBy Lara Bazelon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden says Americans should decide for themselves if they want to wear masks on public transportation.
description: The decision to wear a mask is “up to them,” President Biden told reporters during a trip.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Tuesday that Americans should decide for themselves whether to wear masks, undercutting efforts by his administration to urge Americans to keep wearing face coverings on airplanes, trains and buses even after a federal judge struck down a nationwide mask mandate on public transport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘The Runaways,’ ‘Brigsby Bear’ and More Streaming Gems
description: This month’s outside-the-box streaming recommendations include quirky comedies, an uncommonly rich music biopic and genre movies that are a cut above.
content: Floria Sigismondi’s chronicle of this all-female 1970s rock band is not immune to the clichés of the period music biopic. But it amounts to far more — a celebration of the punk scene and D.I.Y. spirit, along with the expected (though generous) helpings of sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll. Dakota Fanning is terrific as the lead singer Cherie Currie, a role that proves an ideal vehicle for her hypnotic brittleness, while Kristen Stewart is in fierce form as Joan Jett, and Michael Shannon nearly steals the show as their sleazy manager and producer, Kim Fowley. Best of all, Sigismondi’s throwback aesthetic and Super-16 mm photography keenly evoke the look and feel of the era; it plays less like a period piece than a contemporaneous coming-of-age movie that was locked away for a few decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: San Diego’s Chicano Park Celebrates Its Anniversary
description: Fifty-two years after its creation, the park still represents a struggle for recognition and power in California.
content: SAN DIEGO — Below crisscrossing freeway overpasses and the whooshing of speeding cars is one of the largest collections of outdoor murals in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Can Democrats Turn Their 2022 Around?
description: Midterm elections are around the corner. Sean McElwee and Anat Shenker-Osorio discuss the fights Democrats need to pick to win over voters.
content: With the midterms just over six months away, the electoral prospects for Democrats are looking bleak. President Biden’s approval rating is at 42 percent, around where Donald Trump’s was at this point in his presidency. Recent polls asking whether Americans want Republicans or Democrats in Congress found that Republicans are leading by about 2 percentage points. And with inflation spiking to its highest point in decades, Covid cases rising and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine continuing to send economic and humanitarian shock waves across the globe, things don’t look as if they are going to get better anytime soon.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Sean McElwee and Anat Shenker-Osorio
description: A conversation with Sean McElwee and Anat Shenker-Osorio
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sean McElwee and Anat Shenker-Osorio. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Chang
title: Big Tech Wants to Commodify Your Happiness
description: In Claire Stanford’s “Happy for You,” a struggling academic joins an internet company building an algorithm to quantify human joy.
content: HAPPY FOR YOU By Claire Stanford
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Johnny Depp, at Libel Trial, Denies Ever Striking ‘Any Woman’
description: Mr. Depp sued his ex-wife Amber Heard for an op-ed she wrote saying she was a “public figure representing domestic abuse.” Ms. Heard maintains that he abused her repeatedly.
content: The actor Johnny Depp took the stand on Tuesday in the defamation case he brought against the actress Amber Heard, his former wife, seeking to clear his name from domestic abuse allegations that he said were “not based in any species of truth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fernanda  Eberstadt
title: In Tove Ditlevsen’s World, Happy Families Don’t Stand a Chance
description: Two reissued works of fiction, “The Faces” and “The Trouble With Happiness,” upend domestic life in the Danish writer’s cutting, deadpan prose.
content: THE FACESBy Tove DitlevsenTranslated by Tiina Nunnally
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Enough About Climate Change. Air Pollution Is Killing Us Now.
description: The best reason to stop burning fossil fuels is that air pollution is a threat to our health.
content: In the early weeks of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, doctors noticed a surprising silver lining: Americans were having fewer heart attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: A Quiet Intensity, Matched With Big Ambitions
description: Joe Kahn, the next executive editor of The New York Times, has had a steady rise in journalism. It began with a decision to turn his focus to China.
content: Joseph F. Kahn’s first job out of college in 1987 was covering Plano, Texas, for The Dallas Morning News, and he was impatient at the prospect of a slow career path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Jerrod Carmichael Knows How to Wear the Truth
description: The comedian’s latest HBO special, which explores family secrets and sexual orientation, is as much a therapy session as a stand-up show.
content: Of all that’s remarkable about Jerrod Carmichael’s latest comedy hour — the storied intimacy of the venue (the Blue Note Jazz Club), the spectral aptness of the lighting (kind of blue), the titanic silences, dental work that would thrill any neat freak — two aspects of this HBO special are especially exceptional. One is a matter of carriage. Carmichael is a stand-up comedian. But all he does in this new show is sit. The opening long shot follows him in the snow, headed toward the Blue Note, where he removes his coat and hat and promptly takes a seat upon the stage before a modest, expectant, engaged gathering of what Carmichael wants to feel is a family and what I can only call community support, because winter isn’t all he braves. For one thing, his long body is on a metal folding chair.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Will You Keep Wearing a Mask on Planes and Public Transit?
description: We’re interested in your response to the ruling against a federal mask mandate.
content: On Monday, a federal judge struck down a nationwide mask mandate on airplanes, trains, buses and other public transportation. The ruling left it up to individual airlines and local transit agencies to decide what to do. By late Monday, the nation’s largest airlines had dropped their mask requirements for domestic flights, and the Amtrak rail system had lifted its mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: An Immersive Show Taps ‘an Oracle’ for a Spin on Greek Myth
description: Punchdrunk’s “The Burnt City” adds techno and sake to the story of the fall of Troy, but it brought in a scholar of classical theater to get the details right.
content: LONDON — When Emma Cole, an expert in ancient Greek theater at the University of Bristol, wove through a maze of apartments, back streets and piazzas inside two huge warehouses in South London recently, she excitedly pointed out every nod to Greek mythology that she passed, including a shrine to the goddess Artemis and graffiti written in Linear B, an ancient form of Greek writing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Elon Musk Races to Secure Financing for Twitter Bid
description: The world’s richest man is trying to shore up debt financing, including potentially taking out a loan against his shares of Tesla, so he can buy Twitter for $43 billion.
content: Elon Musk is racing to secure funding for his $43 billion bid to buy Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Russia’s Strategy in the East
description: Russia is taking a more methodical approach in its Donbas campaign.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Concerns Rise as Passenger Masks Fall
description: Health experts expressed dismay at a judge’s ruling that struck down the C.D.C. mask mandate for planes, trains and buses.
content: Public health experts reacted with dismay to a federal judge’s ruling on Monday that struck down a mask requirement for plane, bus and train passengers, expressing concern that the case would set a precedent that erodes the authority of public health agencies and hampers their ability to respond to health emergencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Rolo’s Looks Like a Corner Tavern in Queens. It’s That and Then Some.
description: Three chefs in the savory kitchen and a pastry chef with a knack for focaccia bring remarkable range to a new Ridgewood restaurant.
content: For restaurant critics in New York City, the road forward is often hard to make out, but in the winter of 2020-21 the visibility was so low I sometimes felt I was driving in a blizzard. New restaurants were opening, but not in the usual sense; indoor dining was banned for the second time since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Strike Is Averted as Doormen’s Union Reaches Contract Agreement
description: The contract with Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, which represents workers at more than 3,000 apartment buildings in New York City, had been set to expire on Wednesday.
content: The union representing doormen and other workers in more than 3,000 apartment buildings in New York City reached a new contract agreement on Tuesday, averting a strike that could have left thousands of tenants standing guard in lobbies, sorting mail and hauling trash to the curb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: Father Doesn’t Know Best at New Directors/New Films
description: Returning to an in-person event, this year’s adventurous festival is filled with discoveries that use families to explore contemporary life.
content: In a springy sign of optimism — illusionary or otherwise! — this year’s New Directors/New Films is returning to theaters full throttle. New York’s Covid numbers are creeping up again, but the festival, a joint venture of Film at Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, has ditched the virtual for the physical. So, if you would like to check out the selections at the 51st edition, which runs through May 1, you will need to do so in person. And while masks are not required, they are recommended by the organizers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Greenberg
title: A Daughter Tries to Make Sense of Her Mother’s Suicide
description: In “Stepping Back From the Ledge,” Laura Trujillo brings a journalist’s eye and a family member’s agony to a bottomless loss.
content: STEPPING BACK FROM THE LEDGEA Daughter’s Search for Truth and RenewalBy Laura Trujillo
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Better.com announces more layoffs, citing mortgage market turbulence.
description: The mortgage lender cut its staff again after firings in December and March, including one conducted on a mass Zoom call.
content: The mortgage lender Better.com announced another round of layoffs on Tuesday after cutting roughly 900 people late last year in a mass firing over Zoom that drew swift backlash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: For passengers in midflight on Monday, there were cheers and alarm as a U.S. mask mandate ended.
description: Airport terminals and flights erupted in applause, while some passengers said the abrupt policy change put them at risk.
content: Halfway into her flight from Atlanta to Los Angeles Monday night, Brooke Tansley heard the pilot’s voice pipe up through the public address system, apologizing for the interruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Man Charged in Fatal Subway Push Deemed Unfit for Trial
description: Martial Simon will be committed to a locked psychiatric facility. He had bounced between hospitals and the streets for years.
content: Martial Simon, the schizophrenic man accused of fatally shoving a woman in front of a subway train in January, will be sent to a locked psychiatric facility indefinitely, after prosecutors agreed Tuesday not to contest a finding that he is unfit to stand trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York Revives Its Alternate-Side Parking Ritual. Cue the Outrage.
description: New York City says that drivers will have to move their cars twice a week again so that dirty streets can be swept clean.
content: In the streets of New York, a ritual is set to clockwork: At an appointed hour, an untold number of New Yorkers descend from their homes to do what they must to avoid a parking ticket for disregarding street-cleaning rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Cora Engelbrecht and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Despair in Mariupol’s last stronghold: ‘They’re bombing us with everything’
description: A huge Soviet-era steel mill is where the last Ukrainian defenders of Mariupol have taken refuge as Russia’s battle to take full control of the city appeared to be entering its final stages.
content: DNIPRO, Ukraine — Under incessant fire from the air and with Russian troops closing in, a group of Ukrainian soldiers holed up in the besieged city of Mariupol issued a message of despair on Tuesday evening, expressing hope that their own forces would come to their rescue and demanding that the world do something to stop the Kremlin’s vicious war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: The Museum of the American Revolution Receives $50 Million
description: The gift, from the estate of its founding chairman, H.F. Lenfest, will nearly double the Philadelphia museum’s endowment.
content: The Museum of the American Revolution, home to George Washington’s restored field tent and many other wartime artifacts, has received about $50 million from the estate of its founding chairman, H.F. Lenfest, who was known as Gerry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Constructive Criticism
description: How open are you to criticism?
content: A study published online last month found that most people are reluctant to share constructive criticism even if it would ultimately be useful to the other person. The same study found that most people would genuinely like to hear that type of feedback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: KYU, an Eclectic Miami Transplant, Opens in NoHo
description: Innovative mussels in the meatpacking district, an ode to Southern Italy in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and more restaurant news.
content: Reversing a trend, a Miami restaurant is opening in New York. Since 2016, KYU (pronounced “cue”), in the Wynwood neighborhood of Miami, has been a destination, offering an eclectic, strongly Asian-leaning menu of often wood-fired specialties served in a high-decibel industrial setting. Appetites are vigorously satisfied; creature comforts less so. In New York, there are touches of luxury in the generous space that housed Bobby Flay’s Gato, with dramatic lighting and a glittering sweep of brass mesh to set off the lounge area. Alan Omsky and Jordan Sayfie, the founders, have joined with an English hospitality company, Reuben Brothers, for this expansion of the brand. (There’s already an offshoot in Mexico City, and other locations are in the pipeline.) Its signature is Japanese yakiniku grilling, which will be handled in an open kitchen with a chef’s table by Chris Arellanes, who worked at Per Se and Eleven Madison Park. Smoked Wagyu brisket, whole roasted cauliflower, six-hour smoked short ribs and a towering coconut cake are coming to New York, along with a newly conceived wood-fired bass with fermented brussels sprouts and dashi, and charred sunchokes with Parmesan cream and togarashi lime. The restaurant’s Miami cocktails, like the Wynwood Mule made with house-smoked pineapple, and the spicy shiso sour fueled with Thai chile tincture, are also traveling north. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Deeply Personal Look at the Past, Present and Future of Hong Kong
description: Louisa Lim’s “Indelible City” charts the place’s reinventions and the author’s experience living there since she was a child.
content: For an authoritarian regime facing a restive population, it’s an ugly version of the Goldilocks conundrum: How to exert just the right amount of repression to quell demands for democracy, without going so far that you provoke disparate voices to unite in solidarity and opposition?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Violent Death That Ended a Love Story
description: GuiYing Ma was attacked while sweeping a sidewalk in Queens, during a time of rising crime against Asian Americans.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at a heartbreaking story about the violence that people of Asian descent continue to face in New York. Also, we’ll make sense of how alternate-side parking rules are changing, and we’ll get a glimpse of a dress that Judy Garland wore in “The Wizard of Oz.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Sent Love Through Our Thumbs’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: In late 2020, I got very sick. After many months, specialists and dollars, there is still only a guess: long-haul Covid. I couldn’t breathe properly. An alien lived inside me. I was single, scared. What if something happened to me? My friend asked me daily for my “thumb status,” even though he hates texting because he says his thumbs are too big. On rare good days, I sent photos with a thumbs up. More were neutral thumbs. Most were thumbs down. Pain. Fatigue. Fear. Every day he asked. Every day I answered. Every day we sent love through our thumbs. — Emily O. Gravett
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Omicron Was More Severe for Unvaccinated Children in 5-to-11 Age Group, Study Shows
description: Black children who had not been immunized made up about a third of those hospitalized during the winter surge.
content: Unvaccinated children from 5 to 11 years old were hospitalized with Covid at twice the rate of vaccinated children during the winter Omicron variant surge, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Melina Delkic
title: Uber and Lyft end mask requirements for riders and drivers.
description: The ride-hailing services made their announcements after a federal judge struck down the government mask mandate.
content: Lyft said on Tuesday that it was lifting its masking requirements in the United States,  joining many airlines and other transportation companies relaxing Covid-19 rules after a federal judge overturned a government mandate that people keep their faces covered on public transportation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: ‘Mummified’ Body Is Identified as Man Missing Since 2020
description: A worker renovating the Henry J. Kaiser Convention Center in Oakland, Calif., found the remains on March 9. A serial number on a plate in his ankle unlocked the mystery of his identity.
content: A construction worker was tearing out a wall inside a century-old Beaux-Arts convention center in Oakland, Calif., on March 9 when he made a gruesome discovery: a mummified body, believed to be that of a man in the “late stages of decay,” a police spokeswoman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll and Justin J Wee
title: A Daring Dream and a Lifelong Love, Dashed in a Moment of Violence
description: GuiYing Ma built a modest life of service in New York until a shocking attack tore her from her devoted husband.
content: Their plans were bold, with no room for devastation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Camhi
title: They Populated Louisiana. Against Their Will.
description: In “Mutinous Women,” Joan DeJean relates the little-known history of the prisoners deported in 1719 to French colonies on the Gulf Coast.
content: MUTINOUS WOMENHow French Convicts Became Founding Mothers of the Gulf Coast
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: An Opera Rarity Reclaims Its Spot in the Repertory
description: Jaromir Weinberger’s “Schwanda the Bagpiper” has been given a persuasive new production by the Komische Oper in Berlin.
content: BERLIN — For anyone who has ever left Strauss’s “Ariadne auf Naxos” wishing for more operas in its mode, or craved works that embrace both modernism and melodic wit (with stylish storytelling to boot), there is a show waiting for you: Jaromir Weinberger’s “Schwanda the Bagpiper.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malcolm Foster
title: Working From Home, Japan’s Corporate Warriors Rethink Their Priorities
description: The country’s traditional job-for-life model is eroding, with pressure now coming from workers who want more flexibility, autonomy and control over their careers.
content: TOKYO — Japan is in the midst of en masse hiring season, when a wave of college graduates join companies in formal ceremonies after sweating through the job-interview gantlet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Will Eric Adams Release His Taxes? A Soft ‘No’ Is Now a Qualified ‘Yes.’
description: Mayor Adams initially refused to commit to releasing his tax returns, breaking with tradition and resurrecting questions over his transparency.
content: In New York, top elected officials have long followed the custom of releasing their tax returns, revealing their income, real estate holdings and charitable donations to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: For David McCormick, the Christmas Tree Farm Is a Fraction of His Wealth
description: The Republican Senate candidate’s financial disclosure statement depicts a wealthy man comfortable walking the halls of power.
content: We can say this much with confidence about David McCormick: The man is rich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope and Knvul Sheikh
title: Nervous about flying? Here’s why a mask will still help protect you even if others aren’t wearing one.
description: There is plenty of evidence showing that masks protect the wearer, even when others around them are mask-free.
content: Masks work best when everyone around you is wearing one. That’s because when a person infected with the coronavirus wears a mask, a large percentage of the infectious particles they exhale are trapped, stopping viral spread at the source. And when fewer viral particles are floating around the room, the masks others are wearing are likely to block those particles that have escaped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Get in the Game
description: Olivia Mitra Framke’s puzzle strikes a chord.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor Olivia Mitra Framke, who is making her 10th appearance in the New York Times Crossword! At 1A, Ms. Framke urges us all to get in the game, a suggestion that I took to heart during my solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Mike Lee and Ted Cruz Fought So That One Man Wouldn’t Have to Face the Pain of Defeat
description: They profess to be constitutional conservatives. But that isn’t quite the whole story.
content: Ted Cruz of Texas and Mike Lee of Utah are two of the most prominent “constitutional conservatives” in the Senate. They built their political careers on their supposed fidelity to the Constitution and the original intent of the founding fathers. Cruz made his constitutional conservatism the centerpiece of his 2016 campaign for president, while Lee has written three books on the founding era and presents himself, to the public, as a constitutional scholar rather than a mere politician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: A Door-to-Door Effort to Find Out Who Died Helps Low-Income Countries Aid the Living
description: Many developing countries don’t keep official death records. A novel effort uses “electronic autopsies” to count deaths, and record their cause.
content: FUNKOYA, Sierra Leone — Augustine Alpha begins gently. “Who lives in this home?” he asks the young man, who has come in from the fields to answer his questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Schwirtz
title: Russia’s Thrust in Eastern Ukraine Combines Firepower and New Caution
description: The military campaign that Moscow said it had now begun appears much more methodical than those it pursued in the war’s first days
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Russia’s initial invasion of Ukraine in February relied on a rapid advance of tanks and helicopter assaults deep into the country — two strategies that ultimately failed and cost Moscow a significant number of casualties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case on Limit to State and Local Tax Deductions
description: New York and three other states had argued that the so-called SALT cap imposed as part of a sweeping tax law in 2017 infringed on their sovereignty.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday rejected a bid by New York and three other states to overturn a $10,000 cap on federal tax deductions for state and local taxes that Congress imposed as part of the Trump administration’s sweeping tax overhaul in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Anna Schaverien and Jenny Gross
title: The Next Big Thing in Streaming
description: As subscriber growth slows, Netflix and others show less resistance to introducing ads.
content: Later today, Netflix will report its latest quarterly earnings. Analysts do not have high expectations. The streaming service’s profits are expected to drop by more than 20 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Kearse
title: Janelle Monáe’s Queer, Afrofuturist Literary Debut
description: “The Memory Librarian” translates the themes of her 2018 album, “Dirty Computer,” onto the page.
content: THE MEMORY LIBRARIAN And Other Stories of Dirty Computer By Janelle Monáe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: ‘Big Screaming Headlines’
description: Coronavirus cases have risen in major cities. Hospitalizations have not.
content: A couple of weeks ago, the news was full of stories about high-profile people contracting Covid-19. The list included Attorney General Merrick Garland, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo, Speaker Nancy Pelosi, other members of Congress (like Joaquin Castro, Susan Collins, Adam Schiff and Raphael Warnock), New York Mayor Eric Adams and several Broadway stars (like Sarah Jessica Parker, Matthew Broderick and Daniel Craig).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt
title: More Cautious, Russia Embarks on New Phase of Ukraine War
description: Despite the Kremlin’s new methodical approach focusing on eastern Ukraine, the Russian military still faces some of the same problems that hampered it after the war began.
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Russia plunged into a new chapter of the Ukraine war on Tuesday, intent on capturing the eastern part of the country and crushing Ukrainian defenses without the same blunders that badly damaged Russian forces in the conflict’s initial weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Hope
title: Can We Fall Out of Love?
description: Some scientists think there is hope for the heartbroken.
content: In May 2020, Omar Ruiz found himself with a broken heart. “My wife told me she was no longer in love with me,” and shortly thereafter, the couple, who had been married 11 years, separated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Jacqueline Avant’s Killer Is Sentenced to 190 Years in Prison
description: Aariel Maynor, 30, pleaded guilty to first-degree murder and other charges after he broke into Ms. Avant’s home in December and fatally shot the philanthropist in the back, the authorities said.
content: The man who fatally shot Jacqueline Avant, a philanthropist and the wife of the music producer Clarence Avant, during a burglary at their home in Beverly Hills, Calif., in December was sentenced on Tuesday to 190 years in prison, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: How Long Does Menopause Last?
description: And how will I know when it’s over?
content: Q: How long does menopause actually last? And how do you know when (or if) you are done?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Ex-Chicago Officer Who Killed Laquan McDonald Won’t Face Federal Charges
description: The officer, Jason Van Dyke, had served about three years in state prison for murdering the Black teenager, a killing that put a spotlight on police brutality.
content: Federal prosecutors said on Monday that they would not bring criminal charges against a former Chicago police officer who served about three years in state prison after being convicted of second-degree murder in the 2014 shooting of Laquan McDonald, a Black teenager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: For the Raptors, Scottie Barnes Can Do a Little Bit of Everything
description: Barnes is a finalist for the Rookie of the Year Award. But he has bigger aspirations than that, starting with winning a championship this year.
content: When the Toronto Raptors selected forward Scottie Barnes with the fourth pick of the 2021 N.B.A. draft, some people in the basketball world raised their eyebrows. Jalen Suggs, considered one of the can’t-miss prospects, was still on the board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Restores Climate to Landmark Environmental Law, Reversing Trump
description: A new rule requires agencies to analyze the climate impacts of proposed highways, pipelines and other projects, and gives local communities more input.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced Tuesday that it is restoring parts of a bedrock environmental law, once again requiring that climate impacts be considered and local communities have input before federal agencies approve highways, pipelines and other major projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan, Sophie Kasakove, Tariro Mzezewa, Robert Chiarito and Matt Berg
title: Several large U.S. transit systems have removed mask mandates.
description: Although New York and San Francisco continue to require masks, Atlanta, Philadelphia, Chicago and the nationwide Amtrak rail system have ended mandates.
content: As major U.S. airlines dropped their mask mandates in response to a federal judge’s ruling, public transit systems across the country scrambled to adapt on Tuesday. New York, San Francisco and Milwaukee kept requirements in place, while systems in Atlanta, Chicago, Washington and Philadelphia allowed riders to drop their masks, as did the nationwide Amtrak rail system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Autopsy Shows Officer Shot Black Man in Back of Head, Family Lawyers Say
description: Patrick Lyoya, 26, was killed on April 4 by a Grand Rapids police officer during a traffic stop. The police released videos of the shooting last week, drawing protests.
content: Lawyers for the family of Patrick Lyoya, a Black man shot dead by a white police officer in Grand Rapids, Mich., said on Tuesday that a private autopsy showed he was fatally shot in the back of the head by the officer after a struggle during a traffic stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong and Ana Ley
title: Masks Are Still Required for N.Y.C. Public Transit, Taxis and Ride Shares
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority doubled down on its mask mandate for subways, buses and commuter rail, as airlines lifted their requirements.
content: Riders are still required to wear masks while taking public transportation in New York City, despite a federal judge in Florida’s ruling on Monday to overturn the nationwide mask mandate on planes and public transit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
title: The U.S. Races to Arm Ukraine With Heavier, More Advanced Weaponry
description: Washington and its allies are scouring Central Europe and the world to get Ukraine the weapons it needs for the next phase of the war.
content: BRUSSELS — The race is on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Tiffany Hsu
title: And Now, a Word From Your Streaming Sponsor …
description: Executives at Netflix, Disney+ and other top streaming services, chasing ever bigger subscription numbers, are having a change of heart about commercials.
content: The two titans of the video streaming wars — Netflix and Disney+ — have long resisted commercials, showing a reluctance to have premium series like “Stranger Things” or “The Mandalorian” run alongside commercials hawking dish soap, soda and medications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar’s Health System Is in Collapse, ‘Obliterated’ by the Regime
description: The country is also now one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a medical worker. At least 30 doctors have been killed since the coup, a rights group says.
content: The surgeon was in the middle of operating on a patient when the squad of soldiers entered the hospital looking for doctors to arrest. A receptionist alerted the surgeon, Dr. Kyaw Swar, but it was too late for him to stop the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: The U.N.’s humanitarian chief said he tested positive for the coronavirus after attending in-person meetings.
description: One meeting had included the U.N.’s secretary general, but everyone in the room was wearing masks, a spokesman said.
content: Martin Griffiths, the top humanitarian chief at the United Nations, said he tested positive for the coronavirus on Monday as he was visiting the U.N. headquarters in New York from a recent trip to Afghanistan, Russia and Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Nevins
title: In ‘Deaf Utopia,’ Nyle DiMarco Dreams of Integrating the Deaf and Hearing Worlds
description: “Being Deaf assigned me a battle,” said the model, producer and now writer. His memoir braids his life, his family’s legacy and the history of Deaf rights.
content: Nyle DiMarco’s new memoir, “Deaf Utopia,” begins in the womb. The year is 1989 and his mother, Donna, is hours into labor, straining to communicate with the doctor as he prepares to perform a C-section. Donna is Deaf, but there’s no sign language interpreter present; it would be another year before the passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act, which mandated that hospitals provide them. So it was by reading the doctor’s lips and the notes he wrote out by hand that she gleaned that her newborn twins, Nyle and Nico, were both Deaf too, the fourth such generation in the DiMarco family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Apple’s Zipped Lips on Chips
description: Government officials say we need more computer chips made in America and soon. Why isn’t Apple stressed?
content: U.S. and European officials talk incessantly about making more of the world’s advanced computer chips anywhere other than Taiwan, which they consider vulnerable to Chinese invasion or influence. They’re on a mission to make more chips in the U.S. and Europe and want to spend taxpayer dollars to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: As One Alaskan Museum Closed, a Native Heritage Center Prospered
description: Wells Fargo closed its museum in Anchorage and has given much of its collection of Native artifacts to another institution that focuses on the state’s Indigenous cultures.
content: At the turn of the century, Edward Anton Rasmuson arrived on the Alaska frontier, a Swedish-born missionary there to teach Tlingit children at a time when many small villages did not have public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: China doubles down on coal
description: Choices being made about energy in the country right now will have profound implications for the climate crisis.
content: What happens in China doesn’t stay in China. Certainly not when it comes to global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
title: Global Economic Forecasts Drop as Russia’s War in Ukraine Takes Toll
description: The International Monetary Fund’s new World Economic Outlook expects growth to slow to 3.6 percent this year. The group is one of many to slash their forecasts recently.
content: WASHINGTON — The world economy has entered a period of intense uncertainty as a capricious pandemic and the fallout from Russia’s war in Ukraine combine to fuel rapid inflation and weigh on an already fragile global recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geraldine Fabrikant
title: Where Winslow Homer Went to Fish and Paint
description: In Homosassa, a tiny town along Florida’s Gulf Coast, the famed artist created some of his most luminous watercolors, capturing an area rich in aquatic life.
content: When Winslow Homer first arrived in Homosassa, Fla., to fish in the winter of 1904, he wrote to his brother Arthur: “Delightful climate here about as cool as our September — Fishing the best in America so far as I can find.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Yaqoob Akbary
title: Blasts at Schools in Shiite Area of Kabul Kill at Least 6
description: More than a dozen people were also wounded, one as young as 7. The attacks again challenged the Taliban’s promise of security, and stoked deep-seated fears in the Shiite community.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Several explosions outside an education center and a public high school in Afghanistan’s capital on Tuesday killed at least six people and wounded at least a dozen more, many of them students, including one as young as 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: impending
description: This word has appeared in 249 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word impending has appeared in 249 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 29 in “As Storms Intensify, the Job of TV Weather Person Gets More Serious” by Marc Tracy:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix lost subscribers for the first time in a decade and expects to lose millions more.
description: The company, which had a net loss of 200,000 subscribers in its first quarter, has been facing down a lack of must-see content on its platform as competitors continue to expand.
content: For the first time in a decade, Netflix lost subscribers — 200,000 overall in the first three months of the year — the result of shifting economic forces, increasingly fierce competition from other streaming platforms and the conflict in Ukraine. The announcement, plus the company’s warning that it expected to lose two million subscribers in the second quarter, sent the stock down more than 20 percent in after-hours trading on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Why We Admire Zelensky
description: Ukraine’s president reminds us that democracies can still generate great leaders.
content: Why do we admire Volodymyr Zelensky? The question almost answers itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Gov. Ron DeSantis clears a way to revoke Disney’s special district in Florida.
description: Having criticized the company’s stand on a law restricting classroom discussion of sexual identity, he expanded a special session of the Legislature to target Disney World’s self-governing privileges.
content: In a move widely seen as retaliation, Gov. Ron DeSantis asked Florida lawmakers on Tuesday to consider the “termination” of self-governing privileges that Disney World has held in the Orlando area for 55 years. He acted after Disney, the state’s largest private employer, paused political donations in Florida and condemned a new state education law that opponents call “Don’t Say Gay.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Ukraine’s War Efforts Gain an Unlikely Source of Funding: Memes
description: A campaign using internet memes and merchandise has rallied international public support for Ukraine in its war with Russia.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Christian Borys was at home in Toronto in February trying to find a way to help Ukrainians threatened by war when he decided to print some stickers from an internet meme: the Virgin Mary hoisting an antitank missile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jing Tsu
title: Left Behind by China’s Economic Miracle
description: “Rouge Street,” a suite of three novellas by Shuang Xuetao, gives voice to characters in an industrial region sometimes called China’s Rust Belt.
content: ROUGE STREETThree NovellasBy Shuang XuetaoTranslated by Jeremy Tiang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Johnson Is All Apologies Before Parliament After ‘Partygate’ Fine
description: Though opposition politicians called him out, only one member of his own Conservative party called on him to resign.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced Parliament on Tuesday as an awkward pioneer in British politics: a confirmed lawbreaker who misled fellow lawmakers but remains ensconced in the nation’s highest elected office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China’s Covid shutdowns go far beyond Shanghai.
description: Cities and towns across the country are shutting down, hoping to sidestep the pitfalls and stumbles that Shanghai has faced battling the Omicron variant.
content: All it took was one confirmed Covid case among the 2.4 million residents of Wuhu, a city in the farmland of eastern China, for the government there to lock down residents without warning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Fearing a Trump Repeat, Jan. 6 Panel Considers Changes to Insurrection Act
description: The 1807 law allows a president to deploy American troops inside the country to put down a rebellion. Lawmakers fear it could be abused by a future president trying to stoke one.
content: WASHINGTON — In the days before the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, some of President Donald J. Trump’s most extreme allies and members of right-wing militia groups urged him to use his power as commander in chief to unleash the military to help keep him in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Condemns Florida’s Ban on Math Books for ‘Prohibited Topics’
description: Trevor Noah joked that he wished math text books had critical race theory so “we could have solved racism by cheating and going to the back of the book.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Here’s how U.S. airlines are changing their mask rules.
description: After a federal mandate was struck down, major carriers said masks would be optional on domestic flights.
content: After a federal judge struck down a nationwide mask requirement for airplanes, trains, buses and other public transportation on Monday, the country’s largest airlines said they would stop requiring masks on flights, ending a practice that most carriers followed for nearly two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: A Woman’s Fatal Stabbing Was Streamed on Instagram, Police Say
description: The livestream led the police in Baton Rouge, La., to charge a man on Monday night after they found Janice David’s body in a car.
content: A Louisiana man who appeared to have been on a days-long drug binge with a woman killed her inside a car on Monday in an attack that he streamed online, showing himself stabbing, choking and torturing her, according to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candace Jackson
title: Getting Older and Living in Luxury
description: I visited a new luxury building for older adults in San Francisco.
content: I visited a new luxury building for older adults in San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Taylor Johnston
title: The Tech Bubble That Never Burst
description: For a decade, warnings about a tech bubble have only led to more money flooding into high-growth start-ups. Could this one be it?
content: For a decade, warnings about a tech bubble have only led to more money flooding into high-growth start-ups. Could this one be it?
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Menu That Goes Where It Pleases
description: Rolo’s explores Middle Eastern flatbread, Dutch “war fries” and Sichuan cabbage, but the kitchen tends to come back to Italian food.
content: Rolo’s explores Middle Eastern flatbread, Dutch “war fries” and Sichuan cabbage, but the kitchen tends to come back to Italian food.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Renovation Inspired by a Fallen Tree
description: There’s no better time to renovate, one Westchester family discovered, than when you’ve already got a hole in the roof.
content: There’s no better time to renovate, one Westchester family discovered, than when you’ve already got a hole in the roof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Explosions at Schools in Kabul Kill at Least 6
description: Blasts outside an education center and a public high school in Afghanistan’s capital killed at least six people and wounded several students. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the attacks.
content: Blasts outside an education center and a public high school in Afghanistan’s capital killed at least six people and wounded several students. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Spring Storm Brings Snow to the Northeast
description: Snow blanketed parts of the region while other areas received heavy rain and strong winds leading to power outages and hazardous driving conditions.
content: Snow blanketed parts of the region while other areas received heavy rain and strong winds leading to power outages and hazardous driving conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and The Associated Press
title: Flight Passengers Cheer as Mask Mandate Ends
description: Passengers reacted with both joy and concern after the Transportation Security Administration abruptly stopped enforcing its mask mandate on planes and in airports.
content: Passengers reacted with both joy and concern after the Transportation Security Administration abruptly stopped enforcing its mask mandate on planes and in airports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Meltzer
title: Not Even for a Moment Do Things Stand Still
description: Mourners from across the country gathered among hundreds of thousands of white flags to honor those lost to Covid.
content: Mourners from across the country gathered among hundreds of thousands of white flags to honor those lost to Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Judge’s Reversal of Mask Mandates
description: Readers object to a decision that they say puts lives at risk and puts too much power in one judge. Also: MacKenzie Scott; refugees; A.I. and gambling; math in Florida.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 19, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 19, 2022.
content: Because of an editing error, the Of Interest section on Friday referred incorrectly to Jackie Robinson. While Robinson was the first Black player in the modern era of Major League Baseball after decades of segregated play, there were a small number of Black players in the major leagues in the 1800s.
source.name: The New York Times
